Description: Large part of an East Greek pottery figure vase (plastic vase) in the form of a dove; the body rests on two long feet and tail; head lost, tail damaged. Mould-made from two-piece mould. Traces of white residue on front. Light red-brown clay.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallels from Naukratis (Higgins 1970, no.100, GR 1886,0401.1357), unprovenanced (Higgins 1970, no.101, GR 1951,0731.2) and Centuripe (Higgins 1970, no.102, 1863,0728.429), are all dated late 6th century BC and appear to be of the same fabric. The fabric, parallels and style are consistent with what was previously assigned to Rhodes, but an Ionian origin is now more likely and the piece chimes in with material from Miletus. Other parallels from Thera (Maximova 1927, 95 fig.9:1), Lindos, Ialysus and Bassae are cited by Higgins (1954, 59). Parallel from Kamiros (Jacopi 1929, fig. 106). Jacopi, G. 1929. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos III. Maximova, M. I. 1927. ‘Les vases plastiques dans l’antiquité’. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.021) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5932 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
